docs.lead_paragraph: People who are double-jointed are often believed to be at higher risk for arthritis. But a new study suggests that when it comes to arthritis of the hand, the opposite may be the case. Writing in the journal Arthritis & Rheumatism, the researchers said they had found lower rates of arthritis in the hands of the double-jointed people they studied, even though the subjects came from families with a history of osteoarthritis.
docs.abstract: Dr Virginia Byers Kraus of Duke University Medical Center leads study on correlation between double-jointedness and arthritis of hand; study, published in journal Arthritis & Rheumatism, holds that being double-jointed actually reduces probability of developing arthritis of hand (S)
docs.snippet: People who are double-jointed are often believed to be at higher risk for arthritis. But a new study suggests that when it comes to arthritis of the hand, the opposite may be the case.    Writing in the journal Arthritis & Rheumatism, the researchers...

docs.lead_paragraph: It started with a rash, an odd scatter of itchy bumps across my 8-year-old daughter's arms, legs and bottom. She's prone to weird skin reactions, so I wasn't worried. As I slathered on the steroid cream, Soleil began to cry.

headline.main: Just a Rash, And Then It Took Aim At Her Heart

docs.abstract: Harriet Brown Cases article describes her daughter's experience with Kawasaki disease; Kawasaki is leading cause of acquired heart disease among children; it is unknown what causes infectious disease, named after Dr Tomisaku Kawasaki, who identified it in Japan in 1967; illness is treated with intravenous gamma globulin and high doses of aspirin; those with Kawasaki fare best when treated early (S)
docs.snippet: It started with a rash, an odd scatter of itchy bumps across my 8-year-old daughter's arms, legs and bottom. She's prone to weird skin reactions, so I wasn't worried.     As I slathered on the steroid cream, Soleil began to cry.

docs.lead_paragraph: The field of talk therapy is highly subject to fads and pop marketing, in part because good therapists are often charismatic story tellers, and any advice that helps demystify relationships and soothe mental turmoil is like intellectual catnip. Self-help aisles throb with new titles every year, and daytime talk show hosts regularly chew over psychological issues. Academic researchers can only swallow their objections and hope these waves of pop psychology are doing more good than harm.

headline.main: So Far, Holding Up Under Scrutiny

docs.abstract: Dr Marsha Linehan, who founded dialectical behavioral therapy more than 20 years ago, discusses aspects of therapy and how it was developed (M)
docs.snippet: The field of talk therapy is highly subject to fads and pop marketing, in part because good therapists are often charismatic story tellers, and any advice that helps demystify relationships and soothe mental turmoil is like intellectual catnip.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Am I the only person who still prefers doing things one at a time? My fellow New Yorkers have raised multitasking to an art form. People talk on their cellphones while jogging, do their homework on the subway, listen to books on tape while walking, put on makeup in the back seat of the taxicab and -- always, everywhere, constantly -- talk on their cellphones while they're busy doing something else.

headline.main: Driving? Maybe You Shouldn't Be Reading This

docs.abstract: Multitasking, which has become way of life for most Americans, has been found to be time consuming and potentially dangerous, particularly if individual is driving car; three state have outlawed use of cellphones while driving and 30 states have considered similar legislation; study by University of Michigan psychologists finds that when subjects are asked to perform two or more experimental tasks that overall time to complete tasks takes longer because frontal cortex is constantly having to switch from one task to another; Richard Restak book New Brain: How the Modern Age Is Rewiring Your Mind describes modern multitasking; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Am I the only person who still prefers doing things one at a time?    My fellow New Yorkers have raised multitasking to an art form. People talk on their cellphones while jogging, do their homework on the subway, listen to books on tape while...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- You can treat a snakebite by sucking out the venom. THE FACTS -- Even a New Yorker can tell you how to treat a snakebite in the middle of the woods. Apply a tourniquet, suck out the poison and spit it out. Wrong, experts say. Putting your mouth on a venomous wound is the last thing you should do.
docs.abstract: Study published in New England Journal of Medicine holds that cutting, sucking or cutting off blood supply to venomous snake bite does more harm to patient than good; over 7,000 Americans per year are bitten by poisonous snake; best treatment is to get person who was bitten to hospital for care; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: People who chew aspirin because they do not like to swallow pills, or because they hope to absorb the medicine more quickly, may be opening the door to serious dental problems. A new report in The Journal of the American Dental Association describes the case of two patients who needed extensive treatment because of the practice. It advises dentists to ask patients about their aspirin use if they come across widespread, hard-to-explain erosion of the teeth. The lead author is Dr. Edward G. Grace of the University of Maryland Dental School.
docs.abstract: Dr Edward G Grace of University of Maryland Dental School leads study on impact of chewing aspirin on teeth; study, published in Journal of the American Dental Assn, suggests that chewing aspirin can pave way to serious dental problems and should be avoided; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who chew aspirin because they do not like to swallow pills, or because they hope to absorb the medicine more quickly, may be opening the door to serious dental problems.    A new report in The Journal of the American Dental Association...

docs.lead_paragraph: The truth about cats and dogs: There seems to be no getting away from them. An inspection of more than 800 homes across the country found allergens from both animals in almost every home, even though dogs or cats were present in fewer than half.

headline.main: When a Pet Is Always Underfoot

docs.abstract: Dr Samuel J Arbes Jr, National Institute of Environmental Health Science researcher, leads study on exposure to dog and cat allergens in home; study, published in Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, finds pets allergens in all homes tested, even if there are no pets living in home; suggests that people carry home allergens on their shoes (S)
docs.snippet: The truth about cats and dogs: There seems to be no getting away from them.    An inspection of more than 800 homes across the country found allergens from both animals in almost every home, even though dogs or cats were present in fewer than half.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many parents worry that their children may be harmed by exposure to environmental factors they cannot avoid or control, including pesticide residues on fruits and vegetables, approved food additives, chlorinated drinking water and hormones in milk. They fear electromagnetic fields as a cause of childhood leukemia, a mercury preservative in vaccines as a cause of autism, and alar, a growth stimulant on apples, as a cause of cancer.

headline.main: Back to Basics: The Real Risks to Children

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes most important hazards to children's health; holds that most hazards, including accidents, can be avoided through parental or caregiver vigilance; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Many parents worry that their children may be harmed by exposure to environmental factors they cannot avoid or control, including pesticide residues on fruits and vegetables, approved food additives, chlorinated drinking water and hormones in milk.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert L. Brent has been studying environmental toxicology for nearly half a century. A distinguished professor at Thomas Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, he specializes in the effects of environmental factors like radiation, drugs and chemicals on the developing embryo and child.

headline.main: Calming Parents' Fears About Environmental Hazards

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Robert L Brent, Thomas Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia, professor and Alfred I duPont Hospital for Children, Wilmington, Del, birth defects research laboratory head, discusses environmental hazards and their impact on children and fetal development; Brent contends that there is considerable misinformation about toxic substances and suggests parents not over-react without full understanding of potential risk; National Institutes of Health and Department of Energy sponsored Brent to co-author research paper clarifing facts on environmental hazards; study is published in journal Pediatrics; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Robert L. Brent has been studying environmental toxicology for nearly half a century.    A distinguished professor at Thomas Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia, he specializes in the effects of environmental factors like radiation, drugs...

keywords.value: DUPONT, ALFRED I, HOSPITAL FOR CHILDREN

docs.lead_paragraph: Older women who follow a series of diet and exercise guidelines are less likely to develop cancer, a new study reports, and the better they are about complying with the recommendations, the less likely they are to develop the disease. The guidelines were published in 1997 by the American Institute for Cancer Research as a way to try to reduce the incidence of cancer. Among the 14 recommendations, people were advised to keep their weight down, take part in regular exercise, eat five or more servings of vegetables and fruit a day, and limit their intake of alcohol, red meat and sodium.
docs.abstract: Dr James R Cerhan of Mayo Clinic College of Medicine leads study on success of American Institute for Cancer Research guidelines in helping prevent cancer in women; one out of three American women will develop cancer and study, published in journal Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers and Prevention, suggests number could be significantly lowered if women followed guidelines; guidelines discussed; drawing (S)
